div.head:
Embleme 19. Of the Secrets of Nature.
If you kill one of the fower, they will all suddenly dye.

lg.l: Behold foure brethen here together stand,
One having earth, water the next in hand,
The third holds aire, and fire the fourth alone:
If you would all destroy, kill onely one,
And they will all forthwith resigneresign to death,
Their lives depending joyntly on one breath.

div.head: Discourse 19.
div.ab:
The Poetts doe feignefeign Geryon King of SpayneSpain to have been tricorporealltricorporeal,-
who had oxen of a purple colour, which a dogge with two heads, and a Dragon
with seven were chargdcharged with as warders: and the same Geryon is reported to be
the Sonne of Chrysaor sprung from the blood of Medusa, and that Dragon the-
Sonne of Typhon, and Echidna: which things agreingagreeing with noe hystoryhistory, or truth
of the matter, as it sounds, and making a noysenoise in all Chymicall AllegoryesAllegories,-
they are not without added hereto by us: But by the three bodyes of Geryon wee
meane three faces beheld in one father, according to the sense of Hermes, or as-
others would have it, foure, having regard to soeso many Elements: For of a Qua
drangle ought a triangle to be made, as that made of a circle, soeso this to re
turne into a cicle: And the consanguinity and naturall conjunction of the
bodyes of Geryon, or the Elements is soeso great, that one being overcome or-
killd, the rest allso dye of themselves and putrefy, without the administration
of any manuall force: As to things with two bodyes it is knowne, that one being
dead, the other allso wastswastes and consumes: as in Italy wee have seen a boy-
foure years of age with two bodyes, who absconded the head of his brother cleaving
to him, within his owne body, the other parts hung downe to the navillnavil, where
they were bound or joynd together: But if hee, that hung downe, and being
much lesse, was carryed by the other, Should be touchdtouched about the hands or-
feet too hard, the bigger did hereby feele paine, yea allso hunger, if the lesse
wanted food: And this is the combination and sympathy of nature, whereby
the members and parts of one body, or joynd with another are mutually-
moved and affected together; whereof if one sound and unhurt, yet-
the other doe not thereby necessarily continue sound and unhurt, but if
greivouslygrievously hurt, the rest doe allso sympathize, and perish by the same-
malady: Soe if a neighbour gains much, noe profit thereby accrewsaccrues to his-
neighbour, but if hee Suffers losse by fire, his neighbour receives much-
damage: for your affairesaffairs are in danger when your neighbours house hath-
taken fire: It is not therefore a thing contradictory to truth, for the other
three to dye, by the destruction of one of these foure brethren, seingseeing that
it may happen divers wayes, either by finding the same ends as beginings
of life being borne at one birth both by father and mother, as wee-
have read has happened to some, perhaps by the inclination of the
starrs, or by being joyned together not onely in soules, but allso ligaments
of the body, or by consternation of mind, by strong imagination in time
of pestilence, or by the vow of a league: A certaine heathenish people
livdlived by the name of Pythagoreans in the IndyesIndies under the govern
ment of the great MogullMogul (who now reigns there the nineth of the-
Successors of Tamberlan) amongst whome this ancient custome is hither
to observed, that if the husband dye, his wife is burnd with fire, or as-
now, lives perpetually in the highest infamy, deserted by all, and es
teemdesteemed as a dead woman, which was therefore done, that the wives-
might not kill themselves by poyson for their husbands, unlesse allso-

they were willing to dye: Soe in the Philosophicall worke, one of the bre
thren being dead, the other doe allso perish by fire, not compulsively, but
voluntarily, that they may not survive in sorrow and infamy: or if one be
assaulted with a club, sword, or stone, hee will commence civillcivil warre with
his brethren, as appears in the GyantsGiants sprung from the teeth of a dragon-
opposing Jason, and elswhere allso Cadmus, and soeso they will all fall by-
mutuall destruction: For touch or hurt him that carryes aire, and hee will
insurge against those two together which are nearest to him, namely him
that carryes water, and him that carryes fire, and these will on both sides-
oppose themselves agaynstagainst him that carryes earth, and him that first promo
ted the quarrellquarrel, till they have given and received mutuall wounds, of-
which they dye: For it is thus decreed amongst the brethren, that the more-
earnestly and vehemently they love one another, if once they begin to hate,-
they are not to be reconciled, but pursue one another to death, as the most-
bitter choler is generated from the sweetest honey in a stomackestomach too hott, or the
Liver being corrupted. Kill therefore him that is alive, but soeso, as being dead
